metadata.title: Supply and Demand
metadata.subtitle: Understanding the Market Forces That Set Every Price

content.title: Supply and Demand
content.subtitle: Understanding the Market Forces That Set Every Price

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
Why does rent cost ${{STATE_MEDIAN_RENT}}/month in {{STATE_NAME}}?
And why do some prices change daily while others stay stable?

objectives.description: Describe the law of demand and law of supply and how they work together to determine market prices.
Examine how supply and demand curves interact to create market equilibrium prices in {{STATE_NAME}}.
Recognize factors that cause supply and demand curves to shift in real markets like housing and labor.
Use supply and demand analysis to make smarter personal finance decisions about timing purchases and careers.

terms.definition: The quantity of a good or service that consumers are willing and able to buy at various prices.
terms.example: At $1,500/month rent, 80,000 people want apartments in {{STATE_NAME}}. At $2,500, only 50,000 do.

terms.definition: The quantity of a good or service that producers are willing and able to offer at various prices.
terms.example: At $2,500/month rent, developers build 100,000 units. At $1,500, they only build 60,000.

terms.definition: The price point where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied‚Äîthe market "clears" with no shortages or surpluses.
terms.example: At ${{STATE_MEDIAN_RENT}}/month, the number of renters equals available apartments in {{STATE_NAME}}.

terms.definition: When the entire supply or demand curve moves due to factors other than price (income, preferences, costs).
terms.example: {{STATE_NAME}} population grows ‚Üí demand curve shifts RIGHT ‚Üí equilibrium price rises.

leftPanel.title: Price Goes Up ‚Üí Quantity Demanded Goes Down
paragraphs: Why does this happen? Three key reasons:
1. Substitution Effect: When prices rise, people switch to cheaper alternatives (beef ‚Üí chicken, driving ‚Üí public transit).
2. Income Effect: Higher prices reduce your purchasing power‚Äîyou effectively have less money.
3. Diminishing Utility: The 5th pizza slice isn't as satisfying as the 1st‚Äîyou'll only buy more at lower prices.

highlightBox.text: � The demand curve always slopes DOWNWARD: Higher price = fewer buyers.

infoCard.title: Your Personal Demand Curve:
items: You have a demand curve for everything!

leftPanel.title: Price Goes Up ‚Üí Quantity Supplied Goes Up
paragraphs: Why does this happen? Producers respond to incentives:
1. Profit Motive: Higher prices = higher profits ‚Üí businesses produce more to capture that profit.
2. New Entrants: High prices attract new producers to enter the market (more builders, more sellers).
3. Opportunity Cost: Higher prices justify using more expensive production methods that weren't profitable before.

highlightBox.text: � The supply curve always slopes UPWARD: Higher price = more producers willing to sell.

infoCard.title: Supply in {{STATE_NAME}}:
items: High wages ‚Üí More workers enter field
High rents ‚Üí More landlords rent units
Prices signal where resources should go

content.headerTitle: Market Equilibrium: Where Supply Meets Demand

leftPanel.title: The Price Where Markets Clear
paragraphs: At equilibrium, quantity demanded = quantity supplied. No shortages, no surpluses.
Above equilibrium: Too many sellers, not enough buyers ‚Üí prices fall (surplus)
Below equilibrium: Too many buyers, not enough sellers ‚Üí prices rise (shortage)
Markets naturally move toward equilibrium through the price mechanism‚Äîno central planner needed!

highlightBox.text: ‚öñÔ∏è Equilibrium is where the supply and demand curves INTERSECT.

infoCard.title: {{STATE_NAME}} Housing Market:
items: Low inventory = High demand vs. low supply

layoutData.title: Factors That Move the Entire Demand Curve
paragraphs: When something OTHER than price changes, the whole demand curve shifts left or right:
bulletPoints: Income Changes: Rising incomes ‚Üí demand increases (curve shifts RIGHT)
Population Growth: More buyers in {{STATE_NAME}} ‚Üí demand shifts RIGHT
Tastes & Preferences: Trends, health concerns, or viral products shift demand
Price of Substitutes: Gas prices rise ‚Üí demand for EVs increases
Price of Complements: Coffee prices fall ‚Üí demand for creamer rises
Future Expectations: Expect prices to rise ‚Üí buy now (demand shifts RIGHT)

keyPoint.text: üìä {{STATE_NAME}} population: {{STATE_POPULATION}} with {{STATE_JOB_GROWTH}}% job growth ‚Üí Demand for housing keeps shifting RIGHT.

layoutData.title: Factors That Move the Entire Supply Curve
paragraphs: When production costs or conditions change, the whole supply curve shifts:
bulletPoints: Input Costs: Lumber prices rise ‚Üí supply of new homes decreases (shifts LEFT)
Technology: Better tech ‚Üí can produce more efficiently (shifts RIGHT)
Number of Sellers: New builders enter {{STATE_NAME}} market ‚Üí supply increases
Government Policy: Taxes decrease supply; subsidies increase it
Natural Events: Drought, pandemic, disasters reduce supply (shifts LEFT)
Expectations: Expect higher prices ‚Üí hold back supply now

keyPoint.text: üèóÔ∏è In {{STATE_NAME}}: Rising construction costs + zoning limits ‚Üí Supply can't keep up with demand ‚Üí Prices rise.

scenario.name: Why Are {{STATE_NAME}} Home Prices So High?
paragraphs: Let's analyze the {{STATE_NAME}} housing market using supply and demand:
DEMAND is HIGH because:
SUPPLY is LIMITED because:

content.question: Looking at {{STATE_NAME}}'s data‚Äîpopulation {{STATE_POPULATION}}, job growth {{STATE_JOB_GROWTH}}%, and {{STATE_HOUSING_INVENTORY}} months housing inventory‚Äîwhat would need to change for home prices to decrease?

content.headerTitle: Using Supply & Demand for Smarter Decisions

leftPanel.title: Time Your Purchases Strategically
paragraphs: Buy when supply is HIGH and demand is LOW:
üöó Cars: End of model year (dealers clearing inventory) or winter months (low demand)
‚úàÔ∏è Travel: Tuesday/Wednesday flights (low demand) instead of weekends
üè† Housing: Winter months typically have fewer buyers competing
üëï Clothing: Off-season purchases (winter coats in spring)

highlightBox.text: � In {{STATE_NAME}}, home prices are typically lowest in winter when fewer people are house-hunting.

infoCard.title: Career Planning with Supply/Demand:
items: High demand + low supply = rising wages
Skilled trades: Limited supply as workers retire

content.headerTitle: The Labor Market: You Are the Supply

leftPanel.title: Your Skills Are a Product in the Labor Market
paragraphs: The labor market works just like any other market:
Employers = Demand for workers with specific skills
Workers = Supply of those skills
When demand for your skills exceeds supply, your wages rise!
With {{STATE_NAME}}'s unemployment rate at {{STATE_UNEMPLOYMENT_RATE}}%, the labor market is tight‚Äîemployers are competing for workers.

highlightBox.text: � Choose careers where demand is rising and supply is limited for maximum earning potential.

content.question:
What skills do you have (or could develop) where demand is high and supply is limited?

How can you use supply and demand thinking to maximize your earning potential?

leftColumn.title: ‚ùå Don't Do This
items: Ignore market signals when choosing careers
Think prices are "unfair" rather than signals
Wait to buy if demand is clearly rising

rightColumn.title: ‚úì Do This Instead
items: Wait for supply to catch up after disruptions
Use prices as information to guide decisions
Act quickly in markets with rising demand

takeaways.title: Law of Demand
takeaways.description: Price ‚Üë ‚Üí Quantity Demanded ‚Üì. Higher prices mean fewer buyers (and vice versa).

takeaways.title: Law of Supply
takeaways.description: Price ‚Üë ‚Üí Quantity Supplied ‚Üë. Higher prices attract more producers and sellers.

takeaways.title: Markets Self-Adjust
takeaways.description: Prices rise to eliminate shortages and fall to eliminate surpluses‚Äîreaching equilibrium.

takeaways.title: Prices Are Signals
takeaways.description: High prices signal scarcity and opportunity. Use this knowledge for timing purchases and careers.

questions.question: If {{STATE_NAME}}'s population grows by 500,000 people, what happens to the demand curve for housing? What happens to equilibrium prices?
Why do home prices continue rising when median price is already ${{STATE_MEDIAN_HOME_PRICE}}? Use supply and demand to explain.
Gas prices are higher in summer than winter. Is this a demand shift or a supply shift? Explain.
How can understanding supply and demand help you choose a career that pays well?

main.title: � Market Analysis Workshop
main.description: Tomorrow you'll apply supply and demand concepts to real {{STATE_NAME}} markets: Analyze actual market data, predict price movements, and develop strategies for timing major purchases and career decisions.

steps: Analyze {{STATE_NAME}} housing supply and demand data
Evaluate the labor market for career planning

content.tagline: Building Financial Futures, One Lesson at a Time
